headline: New York Today: Survival Kit Additions
abstract: Tuesday: Readers suggest essential items for New York, Walt Whitman at 199, and Manhattanhenge approaches.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this stunning Tuesday.

headline: Peak Performances Announces Residency and Upcoming Season
abstract: The 2018-2019 season will include a trilogy by Faye Driscoll, Cuban-klezmer opera, environmental acrobatics and a European look at American democracy.
lead_paragraph: Faye Driscoll is the recipient of next season’s PeARL extended residency at Peak Performances at Montclair State University. Three connected pieces by the choreographer are slated for the 2018-2019 season, including a world premiere of the trilogy’s final installment.

headline: How to Keep Track of the Trade Fights: DealBook Briefing
abstract: For those suffering whiplash from the Trump administration’s shifts in trade policy, here’s a way to follow along.
lead_paragraph: Good Tuesday. Want this in your inbox every morning? Sign up here.)

headline: Just Lost an Election? Join the Winning Side
abstract: That’s what Malaysian politicians are doing — and it’s bad for our democracy.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Call them “hoppers,” call them “frogs,” as soon as the surprise outcome of Malaysia’s recent election became clear, politicians from the losing parties started jumping over to the winners’ side. The moment the long-ruling coalition Barisan Nasional was voted out of power on May 9, it started to disintegrate.

headline: Civil Obedience
abstract: We are honoring each of the Top 10 winners of our Fifth Annual Student Editorial Contest by publishing an essay a day. Here, an essay by Anushka Agarwal, age 16.
lead_paragraph: We are honoring each of the Top 10 winners of our Fifth Annual Student Editorial Contest by publishing an essay a day. You can find them all here.

headline: As Chinese ‘Crepe’ Catches On Abroad, a Fight to Preserve Its Soul
abstract: The humble jianbing now has gentrified variations from Beijing to Brooklyn, and a Chinese trade association is trying to set some standards.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When is a pancake not a pancake?

headline: Belgian Inmate on Leave Kills 3 in Liège Attack
abstract: Prosecutors said the attack in the eastern industrial city was being investigated as terrorism.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — A prison inmate on a 48-hour leave fatally shot two police officers and a civilian and then took a woman hostage at a school in the eastern city of Liège on Tuesday, before being killed by the police, officials said. No students were injured.

headline: 1,475 Missing Immigrant Children
abstract: That story isn’t quite what it seems. But another new immigration policy is cause for alarm.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.

headline: Skripal Attack Scared U.K. Doctors: ‘We Were Expecting Them Not to Survive’
abstract: In their first extensive interviews, those who treated a former Russian spy and his daughter described fears that their patients would die, and that many more casualties would follow.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Medical workers in Britain who treated the former Russian spy Sergei V. Skripal and his daughter, Yulia, initially feared that they would be inundated with civilian casualties from a lethal, Soviet-developed nerve agent and that their colleagues had been exposed, they have told the BBC.

headline: Nicolas Ghesquière Still Has Something He Wants to Say at Louis Vuitton
abstract: And he said a lot of it at the brand’s cruise show in the south of France.
lead_paragraph: A few days before his 2019 Louis Vuitton cruise show, held in the Miró labyrinth at the Foundation Maeght in Saint-Paul de Vence, the designer Nicolas Ghesquière put up what seemed like a very strange post on his Instagram account: “Happy to renew my commitment with the beautiful house of @louisvuitton. #notgoinganywhere.”

headline: California Today: The Primary Is Coming. Here’s a Look at the Key Races.
abstract: Tuesday: Hope for the West Coast’s oldest military cemetery, an evangelical fight for voters, and an owl crisis in Silicon Valley.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Converting High Efficiency Image File Photos for Windows
abstract: The HEIF or HEIC container format stores quality photos in smaller file sizes to save space, but not every program can open them yet without help.
lead_paragraph: Q. I manage content on our school’s website, including pictures. A colleague sent me pictures of an event from an iPhone, and they were in HEIC format. I couldn’t open them in Photoshop Elements, and our site won’t accept HEIC files for uploading. What now? I use a Windows PC.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
abstract: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
lead_paragraph: $2.45 MILLION

headline: Pret A Manger, U.K. Sandwich Chain, Is Sold to Food Giant JAB
abstract: The acquisition by JAB, a conglomerate on a quest to create a food-and-beverage empire, would add to a stable of coffee brands and a doughnut chain.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — JAB Holding Company, the deal-hungry conglomerate, has bought dozens of coffee brands and begun branching out to doughnuts. Now, it has set its sights on sandwiches.

headline: Stocks Drop as Italy’s Political Anxiety Spills Across Its Borders
abstract: Italy has not had a new government since holding elections in March. But in the past week, the country’s politics exhibited a new level of unpredictability.
lead_paragraph: Stock markets in the United States dropped Tuesday amid concerns that growing political uncertainty in Italy and simmering tensions over Chinese trade could weigh on global economic growth.

headline: Over, Easy: A Basketball Aficionado Foresees the Warriors’ Surge Past the Rockets
abstract: Fabulous Flournoy, a Bronx native, has been a player-coach for a professional team in Britain for the past 17 seasons.
lead_paragraph: My companion for Game 7 of the N.B.A.’s Western Conference finals was talking about the delicate process of hard-boiling eggs.

headline: Trump, Stung by Being Attacked as Soft on China, Pushes Ahead on Tariffs
abstract: In a reversal, the administration said it would impose tariffs and other measures in the coming weeks, ramping up pressure on China to make trade concessions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump, stung by criticism that he has gone soft on China and less worried about Beijing’s ability to disrupt a potential summit meeting with North Korea, reversed course on Tuesday and declared that the United States would impose tariffs and other punitive measures on China.

headline: Rockets and Celtics Are Doomed by the 3-Point Shot
abstract: The Celtics and Rockets lost largely because they could not make the long shots at home.
lead_paragraph: To win in the N.B.A., it helps to rebound, to block shots and to play defense. But most of all, you need to shoot the ball well. And in the modern game, shooting 3 pointers is one of the most important skills of all.

headline: She Was a Model for Impressionist Masters. Then She Became One Herself.
abstract: Suzanne Valadon was too poor to study art, but as Catherine Hewitt makes clear in a new biography, “Renoir’s Dancer,” she learned a lot by posing for the great painters of her time.
lead_paragraph: RENOIR’S DANCERThe Secret Life of Suzanne ValadonBy Catherine Hewitt Illustrated. 470 pp. St. Martin’s Press. $27.99.

headline: Supreme Court Allows Arkansas Abortion Restrictions to Stand
abstract: In turning down an appeal, the court put two of the state’s three abortion clinics at risk of closing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday refused to hear a challenge to an Arkansas law that could force two of the state’s three abortion clinics to close.

headline: Puerto Rico’s Hurricane Maria Death Toll Could Exceed 4,000, New Study Estimates
abstract: The number of people who died because of Hurricane Maria last year has been a matter of debate. A new study relied on interviews on the ground.
lead_paragraph: As hurricane season begins this week, experts are still trying to count the number of deaths caused by last year’s devastating Hurricane Maria in Puerto Rico. The latest estimate: roughly 4,600, many of them from delayed medical care.

headline: Canadian Government to Buy Kinder Morgan’s Trans Mountain Pipeline
abstract: The decision caps a divisive battle over whether to allow a pipeline expansion that environmentalists say would contribute to climate change and risk spills.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — The Canadian government on Tuesday said it would buy an oil pipeline to the country’s west coast, ensuring that its widely protested expansion will go forward.

headline: You Knew the Warriors Were Coming Back. The Rockets Did, Too.
abstract: Another sublime third quarter. More pain for Mike D’Antoni. “We thought we had it.”
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — There were the Houston Rockets, grabbing rebounds and nailing dunks, and twisting and shouting and opening up a handsome 11-point halftime lead over the reigning champion Golden State Warriors on Monday night.

headline: Malcolm Gladwell Likes Things Better in Canada
abstract: The journalist on mass shootings, not believing in prisons and if Donald Trump has gotten in his 10,000 hours of practice for presidential greatness.
lead_paragraph: You just started Season 3 of your podcast, “Revisionist History,” which explores, as you put it, “the overlooked and the misunderstood.” What’s the most widely misunderstood event in history? Oh, my God. I have no idea. If I knew that, I’d do an episode on it. I think that the premise of the show is that everything is misunderstood in some way, and that there is great virtue in coming to a subject late. In a media culture that is so obsessed with being first, I would like to be last.

headline: Jeans, Made in the … U.K.?
abstract: The British are coming for the United States denim market.
lead_paragraph: “It takes seven people to make our jeans,” said Faye Toogood, the co-founder and designer of the Toogood fashion label, from her studio in east London.

headline: Put a Ring on It? Millennial Couples Are in No Hurry
abstract: Young adults not only marry and have children later than previous generations, they take more time to get to know each other before tying the knot.
lead_paragraph: The millennial generation’s breezy approach to sexual intimacy helped give rise to apps like Tinder and made phrases like “hooking up” and “friends with benefits” part of the lexicon.

headline: A Red-Sauce Joint for Our Times
abstract: Don Angie, in the West Village, updates the recipes and traditions of old-school spaghetti-and-meatballs restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Don Angie, in the West Village, updates the recipes and traditions of old-school spaghetti-and-meatballs restaurants.

headline: Red-Sauce Italian Cooking Finds a Future at Don Angie
abstract: Pasta and meatballs, garlic bread, a house Chianti: This new West Village restaurant brings new vitality and surprise to a familiar cuisine.
lead_paragraph: Ever since Rich Torrisi and Mario Carbone began rehabilitating chicken Parm and Neapolitan cookies around 2010, I’ve been waiting for other restaurants to carry the torch of Italian-American food boldly into the future. This is a major branch of American cuisine, too important for its fate to be left to the Olive Garden.

headline: My Relationship Makes Me Feel Excruciatingly Lonely. But I Love Her!
abstract: A 22-year-old says his relationship makes him miserable. So why does he stay?
lead_paragraph: Dear Sugars,

headline: New Bottled Cocktail Conjures Summer in Capri
abstract: St. Agrestis’s bottled Negroni combines the company’s new aperitif with Greenhook gin and vermouth.
lead_paragraph: St. Agrestis, a Brooklyn spirits company known for its amaro, has introduced a ready-to-drink Negroni. It’s based on their new aperitif, Inferno Bitter, which is making its debut in the bottled Negroni. The cocktail is also made with local Greenhook gin and sweet vermouth for a smooth, balanced drink that reins in the bitterness. Serve it with an orange twist or slice, or top it with prosecco. At 48 proof, the cocktail is sessionable as well as convenient, said Louis Catizone, an owner of the company: St. Agrestis Negroni, 100 milliliters (3.3 ounces), $6.49 a bottle, $24.99 for a four-pack, astorwines.com.

headline: Matcha Meets Its Match
abstract: At Pondicheri, powdered moringa adds a boost to a frozen dessert.
lead_paragraph: The flood of so-called super foods from the tropics continues nonstop. Moringa — a tree that grows in hot, arid climates — has leaves that are dried and turned into a powder rich in calcium, vitamin A and protein. Alone the powder is fairly bitter, so it’s best added to smoothies and sauces. At Pondicheri, an Indian restaurant in NoMad, moringa bolsters verdant avocado ice cream. The generous scoops are rolled in chopped pistachios and more of the powder. Ajna Jai, who manages the restaurant for her mother, Anita Jaisinghani, the owner, thought of using moringa because it made a good alternative to the ubiquitous matcha. “In general, moringa works well in Indian food,” Ms. Jai said: Moringa ice cream, $4 a scoop to eat in or take out, $6 in a cone, Pondicheri, 15 West 27th Street, 646-878-4375, pondichericafe.com.

headline: As Office Parks Empty, Towns Turn Vacancies Into Opportunities
abstract: Once the suburban ideal, sprawling office parks are quickly becoming relics that stress local tax bases. But they also offer redevelopment possibilities.
lead_paragraph: WAYNE, N.J. — Perched off a busy road in northern New Jersey with sweeping vistas of a vast reservoir sits a new relic of the suburban panorama: the international headquarters of Toys “R” Us slogging through its final days after the company announced that it would be shutting down for good.

headline: Review: A Bus Crash, a Breakup and More Reverberations in ‘Tremor’
abstract: Brad Birch’s psychological thriller finds former lovers warily circling each other in Wales.
lead_paragraph: She shows up on his doorstep in the middle of the day, while his wife and toddler son are out. It’s been four years since Tom and Sophie were together, and as he lets her into his home you can feel his wariness. He’s moved away from their old town in the north of Wales, started a new life, tried to disappear. What does she want with him now?

headline: After Racist Tweet, Roseanne Barr’s Show Is Canceled by ABC
abstract: Ms. Barr cited “The Planet of the Apes” in discussing Valerie Jarrett, a black woman and former adviser to President Barack Obama. ABC Entertainment’s president called it “abhorrent.”
lead_paragraph: Two months ago, Roseanne Barr was a star again.

headline: A Search for MH370, Missing Since 2014, Ends ‘With a Heavy Heart’
abstract: No evidence was found of the plane, a Boeing 777 operated by Malaysia Airlines, that deviated from its planned route in March 2014 for reasons that remain unknown.
lead_paragraph: The latest search for MH370 — the Malaysia Airlines plane that disappeared four years ago en route from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing with 239 people onboard — has ended in failure, the company behind the search said on Tuesday.

headline: Los Viajeros Brings Its Food Truck Menu to Turnstyle
abstract: Ropa vieja-filled tacos, chorizo quesadillas and fish burritos are among the items available in the food hall at Columbus Circle.
lead_paragraph: By now the trajectory is familiar: You scratch together the wherewithal to start a food company, perhaps selling at first in one of the city’s open street markets, then setting up a truck and finally, if all goes well, opening a more permanent store or a stand in an indoor food court. Los Viajeros, opening in Turnstyle on Friday, is the work of Caitlyn Napolitano and Carlos Dacosta. The couple has a weekday food truck, serving Latin specialties, stationed in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens. The Turnstyle menu will be the same, including tacos filled with Cuban-style ropa vieja, chorizo quesadillas, fish burritos and the like: Los Viajeros, Turnstyle, Columbus Circle station, losviajerosfoodtruck.com.

headline: How to Exfoliate, Without Damaging Your Skin
abstract: The latest resurfacing toners aim to clean your pores and calm your skin at the same time.
lead_paragraph: Few beauty practices are embraced as enthusiastically as exfoliation — dermatologists have long said that a good polishing can banish dullness, clean pores and reveal fresh, glowing skin in a matter of minutes. It’s a deeply satisfying ritual. And yet, it’s easy to get carried away. Buffing too often with abrasive scrubs, sponges and facial brushes can obliterate everything — dead skin cells, yes, but also healthy oils and enzymes — leading to inflammation, redness, irritation and even “profound hyperpigmentation,” especially on darker skin tones, says Sumayah Jamal, M.D., of Schweiger Dermatology Group in New York City.

headline: They’re Out of Prison. Can They Stay Out of the Hospital?
abstract: Community health workers who used to be locked up themselves are helping recently released inmates get care for mental illness, addiction and other health problems.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The night Ronald Sanders turned his life around, he had been smoking crack for two days in a tiny, airless room. His infant son, Isaiah, was breathing in the fumes. “His chest was beating really hard,” Mr. Sanders recalled. “So I pray: ‘If my son makes it through the night, that’s it.’”

headline: Soy Sauces With Texas-Size Flavors
abstract: Ink Gourmet makes the condiments in six flavors, including orange-chile and wasabi.
lead_paragraph: You can find both regular or low-sodium soy sauce, with or without wheat. Now, Ink Gourmet, a company based in Mesquite, Tex., sells it in six flavors. The orange-chile version, thicker than regular Chinese soy sauce, is meant to turn that simple stir-fry into the popular orange chicken or beef. Wasabi, lemongrass and Thai chile are some other options: $10.99 for eight ounces, lower prices for several bottles, inksoysauce.com.

headline: Organic Egg Ratings at Your Fingertips
abstract: A resource helps consumers navigate labels on about 150 brands of eggs.
lead_paragraph: It’s worth studying the many shades of organic, especially regarding eggs. The organic label can be slapped onto cartons of eggs laid by hens crowded in semiconfinement on megafarms, as well as on those from hens that scratch outdoors for dinner. The Cornucopia Institute, a nonprofit agricultural watchdog group that reveals industrial practices within the elastic organic standards, began rating eggs over five years ago. The ratings, updated last year, are based on how the birds are raised. About 150 local and national brands are judged at one to five eggs, the highest mark. The organization does not have an app yet, but Mark Kastel, a founder, said the online chart is mobile friendly. Yogurt and other dairy products, pet foods and more have also been evaluated on the website: cornucopia.org.

headline: One Door Closes, and an Uber Door Opens. Love Follows.
abstract: For some people, car services like Uber and Via provide more than just transportation. They turn out to be vehicles for meeting their beloved.
lead_paragraph: Fourteen minutes and 35 seconds. That’s how long it took Ed Santos and Jill Sciuto’s futures to radically alter course. Less than 15 minutes. A car ride from Manhattan to Brooklyn.

headline: The European Union Is Under Threat. Artists Say It’s Time to Rebrand.
abstract: A group led by Wolfgang Tillmans and Rem Koolhaas is discussing how the organization can “be recognized as a force for good, rather than as a faceless bureaucracy.”
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — With populist politicians across the Continent attacking the European Union and negotiations underway for Britain to leave the bloc, the very idea of a unified Europe seems to be under threat. Some artists feel the union needs to rethink its public image and refine its communications strategy to combat these attacks. In other words: to rebrand Europe.

headline: In ‘Harlequinade,’ Gestures Dance, and Dances Tell Stories
abstract: Alexei Ratmansky is restaging Marius Petipa’s ballet not by patching together known versions, but by going to back to a written source.
lead_paragraph: We think of ballet as a nonverbal art, but for the last few months, the words “tell” and “say” have echoed in the studios of American Ballet Theater. The dancers aren’t using their voices; it is their bodies that are doing the talking.

headline: Butter Tarts Clear Customs
abstract: Btarts, a new pastry company based in Brooklyn, ships the sugary Canadian treat nationwide.
lead_paragraph: Butter tarts are to Canada what natas are to Portugal, mellow little dessert pastries sold and served everywhere. In Canada, a flaky tart shell holds a dense, sweet sugar custard not unlike pecan pie filling. Longing for butter tarts after moving to the United States from Toronto, Asher Weiss adapted his great-grandmother’s recipe and is producing them in Brooklyn. They’re sold at Smorgasburg and nationwide: Btarts, $5 each, $27 for six at Smorgasburg, $59 for six online (includes shipping), $89 for 12, eatbtarts.com.

headline: In the Stanley Cup Finals, Alex Ovechkin’s Legacy Continues to Evolve
abstract: Ovechkin has become a somewhat paradoxical figure: the reason for the Capitals’ success — and the reason for their playoff failures.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The four other Washington Capitals starters had assembled along the blue line Monday night for the singing of the national anthem, but Alex Ovechkin just kept skating in circles, one after another after another.

headline: Farm-to-Table in the Shadow of Downtown Detroit
abstract: In her “no-waste kitchen” at Lady of the House, Kate Williams sees a way of investing in her city and the farmers three blocks down.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Selling a vegetable as a steak is asking for trouble, unless your customers have never eaten a steak. Even the finest kohlrabi shouldn’t have to pretend it’s a rib-eye. But if any slab of plant matter can survive the comparison, it’s the carrot steak at Lady of the House in this city’s Corktown neighborhood.

headline: Serena Williams ‘on the Right Track’ at the French Open
abstract: With palpable intensity and a bodysuit full of meaning, Williams won her first match at a Grand Slam tournament in nearly 16 months.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Grand Slam tennis, like so much in life, is an expectations game.

headline: Police Need Warrants for Driveway Searches, Supreme Court Rules
abstract: The case concerned a stolen motorcycle covered in a tarp that an officer had looked under without an invitation or a warrant.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday that police officers must generally have warrants to enter a home’s driveway in search of stolen vehicles.

headline: Scared of High-Intensity Interval Training? A Heart Monitor Can Make It Fun and Easy
abstract: The popular fitness trend sounds brutal. But a simple tool can make it speed by.
lead_paragraph: High-intensity interval training is one of the biggest trends in fitness, but it has always seemed a bit scary to me. To a mere mortal with achy knees and an aging body, even the acronym — H.I.I.T. — sounded intimidating.

headline: Looking for a Bit of Shade as Intense Heat Wave Hits Karachi
abstract: Extreme temperatures, power failures and Ramadan strictures combine in a grueling ordeal for the Pakistani city of 20 million people. Some have died.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — Heat waves have become common this time of year in Karachi, Pakistan’s sprawling seaside port city. Still, the latest one caught its 20 million residents off guard.

headline: Shari Redstone Fires Fresh Volley in Legal Battle for Control of CBS
abstract: A new lawsuit suggests that a proposed merger between CBS and Viacom was just step one in a larger plan. It also asserts Ms. Redstone’s control of CBS.
lead_paragraph: Shari Redstone, the CBS Corporation’s main shareholder, moved on Tuesday to quell a rebellion at the media company, filing a lawsuit that accused the CBS board of directors of improperly trying to strip her of control.

headline: An Alabama Chef and Her Beloved Desserts Hit the Big Time
abstract: After 30 years of thrilling customers, Dolester Miles has been anointed the nation’s best pastry chef — though she’s not making a big deal about it.
lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — Dolester Miles bought a pair of black slacks and a sequined blouse to wear to the James Beard Foundation awards ceremony in Chicago this month. She wanted to look nice, even though she didn’t think she was going to be chosen pastry chef of the year.

headline: On Paid YouTube, Sci-Fi Comedy and the Grown-Up Karate Kid
abstract: YouTube Red, soon to be YouTube Premium, is taking baby steps toward competing with the Netflixes of the world (for $12 a month).
lead_paragraph: With Netflix, you get what you pay for. With YouTube, you get what you’re willing to sit through a pre-roll ad for. That’s a fundamental reason the two are the alpha and omega of online streaming: neatly organized television-length (and TV-quality) programs versus an endless babel of mostly short bursts of video.

headline: American M.M.A. Fighter Granted Russian Citizenship
abstract: Jeff Monson had professed a desire for at least five years to officially become a Russian.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Monson, a prominent American mixed martial arts fighter, has been granted Russian citizenship, the government announced Tuesday, becoming the latest fading Western star to be given a passport.

headline: In 1973, an Arsonist Killed 32 People at a Gay Club. Why Has History Shrugged?
abstract: In “Tinderbox: The Untold Story of the Up Stairs Lounge Fire and the Rise of Gay Liberation,” Robert W. Fieseler reports on an all but forgotten tragedy in New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: To those who loved the Up Stairs Lounge, it was a kind of paradise.

headline: Conjuring Spirits at the Tap Family Reunion
abstract: In “Raising the Bar,” part of a weekend of tap events, the dominant feeling was love of tradition.
lead_paragraph: A line of people spilled off the sidewalk in front of the Schomburg Center in Harlem early Friday evening, waiting to get inside. As more people arrived, they were greeted with waves, hugs and murmurings of “It’s been a long time.” If you had guessed it was a gathering of friends and relatives, you would have been mostly right. It was the opening event of the Tap Family Reunion.

headline: Myanmar Is Intensifying Violence Against Ethnic Minorities, U.S. Says
abstract: A new campaign is targeting the largely Christian minority in Kachin state, and an unknown number of Rohingya are displaced throughout Myanmar, a State Department report on religious freedom says.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Myanmar’s military campaign to kill or drive away its ethnic minorities is worsening despite a growing international outcry, according to a State Department religious freedom report that was released on Tuesday.

headline: Lawyer Says Weinstein Had a Romantic Relationship With Woman Accusing Him of Rape
abstract: The woman prosecutors say was raped by Harvey Weinstein had a 10-year consensual relationship with him before and after the incident, his lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: A lawyer for Harvey Weinstein said on Tuesday that the woman prosecutors say Mr. Weinstein raped at a Manhattan hotel in 2013 had a decade-long romantic relationship with him both before and after the alleged attack.

headline: Lawyers in Cohen Case to Appear in Court to Negotiate Disputes
abstract: Some of the arguments are sober. Some are circuslike. Both stem from the raids last month on Michael Cohen’s apartment, hotel room and office.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to President Trump’s legal health and welfare, few recent events have borne as much potential risk as the extraordinary raids that federal agents conducted last month on Michael D. Cohen, his longtime lawyer and fixer. Seizing boxes of documents and about a dozen cellphones, iPads and computers, the agents were looking for evidence that Mr. Cohen broke the law in his wide-ranging business deals — among them, hush-money payments that he made to women who claimed they had affairs with Mr. Trump.

headline: Opening Night of Stratford Festival Canceled Following Bomb Threat
abstract: A performance of “The Tempest” was canceled after the Stratford police received a bomb threat, but a search did not turn up any suspicious package.
lead_paragraph: The actress Martha Henry was about to summon a storm as Prospero in “The Tempest” when a real-life crisis intervened: The opening night of the Stratford Festival in Ontario, Canada, was canceled on Monday night after a bomb threat was called in to the police. Following a search, the area was deemed safe, and the festival announced that performances would resume on Tuesday.

headline: Starbucks’s Tall Order: Tackle Systemic Racism in 4 Hours
abstract: The coffee chain closed its U.S. stores for several hours to improve its image after the arrests of two black men at a store in Philadelphia brought heavy criticism.
lead_paragraph: For Starbucks, the scope of companywide anti-bias training on Tuesday was easy to measure. Roughly 175,000 employees at 8,000 locations pored over nearly 23,000 iPads, learning about the processing power of unconscious brains and the roots of unconscious bias.

headline: New Jersey Town and University Bridge Their Divide, and Both Reap a Reward
abstract: Rowan University and the Borough of Glassboro overcame years of distrust to revitalize the downtown area with retail, restaurants and student housing.
lead_paragraph: GLASSBORO, N.J. — Joseph A. Brigandi Jr. remembers when his father ran a sub shop in the heart of this southern New Jersey town in the 1960s, when there were only four or five restaurants downtown and no out-of-town shopping malls threatened the survival of local businesses.

headline: A Hero’s Plea on Memorial Day
abstract: Picking Paul Bucha, a Medal of Honor recipient, as a speaker was predictable. His message about black men in America wasn’t.
lead_paragraph: Paul Bucha is about as safe and predictable a Memorial Day speaker as you could book in largely white, largely rich Greenwich, Conn.

headline: It’s Not the Ground at Arlington Cemetery That’s Sacred
abstract: The Army’s proposal to restrict the military burial ground would ignore its true meaning.
lead_paragraph: Arlington National Cemetery, the final resting place for more than 420,000 veterans and their families, is facing a space shortage. At its current rate of approximately 7,000 interments annually, it is estimated that the cemetery will be full in about 25 years.

headline: The Problem With Body Positivity
abstract: We‘re not helping fat girls by telling them that every single problem can be solved by learning to love themselves.
lead_paragraph: Everything I thought I knew about body positivity had somehow become wrong.

headline: Don’t Try to Catch a Komodo Dragon — Unless You’re David Attenborough
abstract: In his new memoir, “Adventures of a Young Naturalist,” Attenborough tells stories from the nature show that first brought him to the animals.
lead_paragraph: ADVENTURES OF A YOUNG NATURALISTThe Zoo Quest ExpeditionsBy David AttenboroughIllustrated. 400 pp. Quercus. $26.99

headline: I Have Updated My Personal Privacy Policy
abstract: While the G.D.P.R. is a European law, my policy applies to everyone, since I don’t really have any friends who live in Europe.
lead_paragraph: Please note that as of today, I have changed my terms and conditions and updated my Personal Privacy Policy in accordance with the European Union’s General Data Protection Regulations. While the G.D.P.R. is a European law, my Personal Privacy Policy applies to everyone, since I don’t really have any friends who live in Europe. These changes are aimed at clarifying the information I collect and how I use it.

headline: Trump’s Claim of a Spy Planted in His Campaign
abstract: Two readers dismiss his claim as “hokum,” paranoid or an attempt to deflect attention from other matters.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Trump Officials, Moving to Break Up Migrant Families, Blame Democrats
abstract: Administration officials argue that court rulings and laws give them little choice, but Democrats have denounced the new policy and rejected attempts to pin it on them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Trying to turn the tables politically on President Trump’s own immigration policy, administration officials on Tuesday defended new measures they are taking to separate children from migrant parents who cross the United States’ southern border without authorization, blaming the situation on Democrats who have bitterly denounced it.

headline: The Profound Social Cost of American Exceptionalism
abstract: Rich and technologically advanced, the United States continues to accept a degree of dysfunction that would be intolerable in any other rich society.
lead_paragraph: When I wrote my first Economic Scene column six years ago, the unemployment rate languished at 8.2 percent as the job market painfully recovered from the jolt of the Great Recession. By last month, only 3.9 percent of working-age Americans who sought a job didn’t have one.

headline: Stewart Lupton, Singer for ’90s Band Jonathan Fire*Eater, Is Dead at 43
abstract: The songwriter and poet fronted an electric, volatile band that helped inspire a rock revival in New York in the early 2000s.
lead_paragraph: Stewart Lupton, the singer-songwriter whose short-lived ’90s band Jonathan Fire*Eater burned fast and bright, falling short of major-label rock stardom but inspiring a wave of New York acts in the early 2000s, died on Sunday in Salt Lake City. He was 43.

headline: Trump, North Korea, MH370: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Lowe’s Drops Paint Strippers Blamed in Dozens of Deaths
abstract: The retailer says it will stop selling paint strippers that contain two dangerous chemicals. A proposal to ban the chemicals is before the E.P.A.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lowe’s, the large home improvement retailer, announced Tuesday that it will no longer sell paint strippers that contain the chemicals methylene chloride and NMP, which have been blamed in dozens of accidental deaths.

headline: North 3rd Street Market Opens in Williamsburg, Brooklyn
abstract: Middle Eastern fare from the celebrity chef Eden Grinshpan, outdoor dining near the High Line, pizza on a paddle at Eataly and other restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: North 3rd Street Market  Like so many of New York’s food halls, this Williamsburg, Brooklyn, newcomer inhabits repurposed real estate, in this case a handsome brick building that stood empty for some time. It will open in stages, through Monday, with a score of food stands. Many of them, like Di Fara Pizza, Corner Bistro for burgers, and Harvest2Order, where microgreens are grown and freshly cut for salads and bowls, are, for the first time, opening in a food hall. Bien Cuit bakery, Chuko for ramen, La Newyorkina for Mexican confections, Dana’s Bakery for macaroons, Baba’s Pierogies and Chris Cheung’s East Wind Snack Shop, are some of the other spots to open in the food hall. Mrktpl, the company owned by Manny Del Castillo and Jamie Hinojos that developed the market with Leny, the building’s owner, has also invested in the art scene, with local talent creating work for the space. Eventually, there will be a catering hall in the back: 103 North Third Street (Berry Street), Williamsburg, Brooklyn, north3rdstreetmarket.com.

headline: Running Out of Room at Arlington National Cemetery
abstract: A reader suggests that not sending soldiers to fight unnecessary wars is the solution.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A French-Rwandan Rap Star Turned Novelist From Burundi
abstract: Gaël Faye’s “Small Country,” a huge hit in France, lands in the United States next week.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — “It felt like an injustice to me,” said the rapper and novelist Gaël Faye, about having to leave civil-war-torn Burundi in 1995 to come live in France. Mr. Faye, who was 13 at the time, had to contend with the shock of a new culture and moving with his younger sister into the cramped space of his mother’s apartment in Versailles.

headline: Celebrating Refugees
abstract: A high school student writes that “some of us celebrate our diversity as our greatest strength.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Canceling ‘Roseanne’: A Good Move by ABC
abstract: One reader praises the rapid action by ABC; another says to Roseanne Barr, “Spare us the phony apology.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Camilla Dietz Bergeron, Stockbroker Turned Jeweler, Dies at 76
abstract: After a successful career on Wall Street, she became a leading buyer and seller of antique and estate baubles on Madison Avenue.
lead_paragraph: Camilla Dietz Bergeron, who prospered in two divergent vocations, on Wall Street and on Madison Avenue, by proving equally adept at evaluating premium stocks and gem-quality rocks, died on May 20 at a hospital in Manhattan. She was 76.

headline: Twitter Users Respond to Roseanne Barr’s Firing
abstract: Shonda Rhimes, Ava DuVernay and Alex Jones responded to Roseanne Barr’s firing after a controversial tweet.
lead_paragraph: As Roseanne Barr unleashed a tweetstorm that included a racist post against Valerie Jarrett, who was a senior adviser to President Obama, Twitter was filled with impassioned responses, many coming from high-profile users. The conversation only grew louder once ABC announced it had fired Ms. Barr and canceled the next season of her sitcom, “Roseanne.” While some defended her, many condemned her words and applauded ABC for its decision.

headline: Active Shooter Game Is Pulled After Angering Parkland Parents
abstract: The game depicts an attacker creeping through school corridors and shooting civilians. “They are profiting off of the murder of my daughter,” one father said.
lead_paragraph: The online game unfolds from the point of view of an attacker, aiming a weapon down a school corridor or throwing a grenade into an auditorium. The character creeps around corners and up staircases. Bullets spray, blood spatters. SWAT team members are shot dead. Civilians are splayed out on the floor.

headline: Franklin Graham: Mixing Evangelism With Political Activism
abstract: Readers argue that the conservative causes that Mr. Graham champions don’t reflect Christian values.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Kesha Again Blocked From Breaking Contracts With Dr. Luke
abstract: A New York appeals court upheld earlier rulings that the singer could not sue her former producer to get out of her recording agreements.
lead_paragraph: The pop singer and songwriter Kesha, who has for years battled in court to be freed from her recording contracts, cannot pursue a countersuit against her longtime producer Dr. Luke that would void their business relationship, a New York appeals court ruled on Tuesday.

headline: Costume Secrets From ‘Picnic at Hanging Rock’
abstract: The show’s costume designer explains the genesis of the most influential looks from Amazon’s new series.
lead_paragraph: Traveling in a horse-drawn buggy, a group of schoolgirls dressed in white pass through a small Australian town and pull off their gloves, their expressions giddy and relieved. They are headed to a picnic — and a tragedy — in the Australian countryside, and their headmistress, Mrs. Appleyard, had instructed them to wear their gloves until they escape the townspeople’s watchful glares.

headline: George Soros Smears Find New Life in Roseanne’s Twitter Tantrum
abstract: In addition to the racist tweet that ended her sitcom, the comedian falsely called the billionaire Jewish philanthropist a Nazi collaborator.
lead_paragraph: The racist tweet that cost Roseanne Barr her hit ABC sitcom was not the only hateful message that the actress and outspoken conservative shared on Tuesday.

headline: The Mets’ Finger Casualties: First Noah Syndergaard, Then Steven Matz
abstract: A rocky spring gets rockier as the Mets lost two starting pitchers to finger injuries. The injuries were compounded by a loss to the Braves.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — May has been a rough month for the Mets. They have been one of the worst teams in baseball since their hot start to the season and they received the first of two more blows on Tuesday afternoon when they unexpectedly announced that Noah Syndergaard, one of the team’s two reliable starting pitchers, was headed to the 10-day disabled list with a strained ligament in the index finger of his throwing hand.

headline: Morgan Freeman’s Team Demands Retraction From CNN Over Sexual Harassment Report
abstract: A lawyer wrote that the reporter, who said she was herself harassed by Mr. Freeman, lacked “impartiality and objectivity.” CNN stood by the report.
lead_paragraph: A law firm representing Morgan Freeman sent a 10-page letter to CNN on Tuesday protesting a report last week in which several women, mostly anonymous, said they had experienced some form of sexual harassment from the actor.

headline: Missouri’s Governor, a Rising G.O.P. Star, Resigns Amid Scandal
abstract: Mr. Greitens, once seen as a Republican superstar, stepped down. For months, as scandal unfolded around him, he had defiantly refused to quit.
lead_paragraph: Eric Greitens was a decorated Navy SEAL who served in Afghanistan and Iraq, the founder of a veterans’ charity in Missouri and a Rhodes scholar. Chiseled and charismatic, he was elected governor of Missouri and seen by his fellow Republicans as a potential superstar in the party, someone with the brains and political instincts to perhaps rise all the way to the White House.

headline: Libyan Factions Agree to Elections Despite Deep Divisions
abstract: France’s president got competing Libyan leaders to agree on a political framework and elections, but the Libyans stopped short at signing an accord.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The leaders of rival Libyan factions agreed Tuesday to work together on a legal framework for holding presidential and parliamentary elections this December in a deal being pushed by France’s president to bring stability to Libya and stem the flow of migrants to Europe from its shores.

headline: Still Pedaling, Pops?
abstract: On the way home from a bike ride.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Arkady Babchenko, Russian Journalist, Shot and Killed in Kiev
abstract: He fled his homeland last year to escape a campaign of intimidation that he said “was so personal, so scary that I was forced to flee.”
lead_paragraph: [Update: On May 30, Arkady Babchenko appeared at a news conference to announce that his reported killing had been staged as part of an elaborate police operation.]

headline: Roseanne Barr Crosses a Line, and ABC Draws One
abstract: The network’s decision to cancel “Roseanne” over a racist comment will cost it. But when people decide to let racism slide, it costs the rest of us.
lead_paragraph: There is, it turns out, a line. Early Tuesday morning, Roseanne Barr crossed it. And within half a day, ABC, though Ms. Barr had given the network its biggest hit of the past season, enforced it.

headline: China, ‘Roseanne,’ Immigration: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Why Italy’s Political Turmoil Is Causing Financial Angst Elsewhere
abstract: Bankers and investors are worried that Italy, one of the European Union’s biggest economies, may be headed toward a government skeptical of the euro.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Italy’s political convulsions have raised new fears about the future of the euro, the single currency of the European Union that was introduced 16 years ago.

headline: Sounding Code Red: Electing the Trump Resistance
abstract: Vote for a Democrat — any Democrat!
lead_paragraph: With the primary season winding down and the midterms soon upon us, it’s time to point out that this election is not about what you may think it’s about. It is not a choice between the particular basket of policies offered by the candidates for House or Senate in your district or state — policies like gun control, right to choose, free trade or fiscal discipline. No, what this election is about is your first chance since 2016 to vote against Donald Trump.

headline: Andy Warhol in the Powder Room. Christopher Wool on the Floor.
abstract: Two working artists, two children, a dog and a sprawling art collection. There’s room for all of it in their Los Angeles studio space.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Where Koreatown and Silver Lake meet Historic Filipinotown — beyond a construction site and a tent city and behind a thick metal gate — lies a Shangri-La, the 22,000-square-foot studio of the husband and wife artists Jonas Wood and Shio Kusaka.

headline: After Juror Drops Out, Deliberations Begin Again in Mangano Trial
abstract: Amid ill juror was replaced and the panel was told to restart deliberations in the corruption trial of a former Nassau County executive.
lead_paragraph: CENTRAL ISLIP, N.Y. — Jurors in the federal bribery trial of Edward Mangano, the former Nassau County executive, began deliberations anew on Tuesday after an alternate replaced one of the existing jurors amid assertions that the atmosphere in the jury room had turned noxious.

headline: Mike Bryan Takes the Court Without His Twin Brother and Loses
abstract: Bryan played 76 consecutive Grand Slam events with his twin brother, Bob, and won 16 of them. He fell in the first round of the French Open with Sam Querrey as his partner.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Mike Bryan hasn’t had to go it alone much since he was born. Four decades and one month later, he has decided he doesn’t want to make a habit of it.

headline: ‘Roseanne,’ the Reboot: A Timeline
abstract: It started with an attempt by ABC to reach viewers whom executives at the network felt they had ignored. It ended suddenly, after two months of big ratings and (mostly) welcome headlines.
lead_paragraph: The day after Donald J. Trump was elected president, nearly a dozen ABC executives meet at the network’s headquarters in Burbank, Calif., and discuss a “heartland strategy” — their pursuit of an audience the network may have overlooked.

headline: Roseanne Barr’s Tweets Didn’t Come Out of Nowhere
abstract: Ms. Barr has a history of insensitive tweets as well as those that endorse fringe conspiracy theories. Here are some of them.
lead_paragraph: Roseanne Barr found herself at the center of a firestorm on Tuesday, after a racist post on her Twitter account compared Valerie Jarrett, an African-American and a former special adviser to former President Barack Obama, to an ape. Her show, “Roseanne,” which had been a ratings hit when it was revived this spring, was swiftly canceled by ABC, scrapping plans for what would have been its 11th season over all.

headline: ‘Solver Stories’ Submission Guidelines
abstract: Have a story that needs to be told about puzzles and how they connected you to someone else? Wordplay wants to hear from you.
lead_paragraph: Wordplay is interested in exploring how puzzles connect us to each other, how they fit into our daily lives and what we can learn about ourselves from solving them.

headline: In Ending ‘Roseanne,’ ABC Executive Makes Her Voice Heard
abstract: Channing Dungey, who canceled the hit sitcom after its star’s racist tweet, was held up as an example of why diversity in Hollywood’s highest ranks is important.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the two years since Channing Dungey took over as president of ABC Entertainment, becoming the first black executive to run a major network, she had largely eschewed the spotlight, avoiding public comments whenever possible and preferring that her work speak for itself.

headline: Disgraced Star Witness Will Not Testify in Albany Corruption Trial
abstract: Todd Howe, once a valuable witness for the government examining corruption in New York, has apparently fallen out of favor with federal prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: Todd R. Howe, the federal government’s disgraced star witness who was arrested midway through his testimony in a recent Albany corruption trial, will not be called to testify in a second such trial scheduled to begin in two weeks, prosecutors disclosed on Tuesday.

headline: Texting About His Day at School, a Santa Fe Student Describes a ‘Nervous’ Return
abstract: In a series of texts, a sophomore described his first day back at Santa Fe High since a gunman killed 10 people there. “This is one of the steps we have to take,” he said.
lead_paragraph: Santa Fe High School opened to students on Tuesday, the first day of school since a teenage gunman opened fire on his classmates and teachers on May 18, killing 10 people.

headline: A Stopgap Government in Italy
abstract: The president blocked a government planned by two anti-establishment parties. The markets shuddered, but Italy may be better off with new elections.
lead_paragraph: It’s not easy to discern a political “crisis” in a country that has had at least 64 governments since World War II, but at the least, the Italian president’s unexpected decision to block the government proposed by two populist parties qualifies as a daring gamble. How it plays out could have major ramifications for Europe.

headline: Fred Kovaleski, Once a Spy in a Tennis Disguise, Dies at 93
abstract: After he was recruited by the C.I.A. during the Cold War, his international tennis career became a cover for espionage.
lead_paragraph: Fred Kovaleski, whose international tennis-playing career became his cover in the 1950s while he was working as a spy for the C.I.A., died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.

headline: Trump Asked Sessions to Retain Control of Russia Inquiry After His Recusal
abstract: The attorney general is a key witness in the investigation into whether Mr. Trump tried to obstruct the Russia inquiry itself.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — By the time Attorney General Jeff Sessions arrived at President Trump’s Mar-a-Lago resort for dinner one Saturday evening in March 2017, he had been receiving the presidential silent treatment for two days. Mr. Sessions had flown to Florida because Mr. Trump was refusing to take his calls about a pressing decision on his travel ban.

headline: Starbucks, at the Intersection of Race and Class in America
abstract: Our photographer drove through parts of Wisconsin, Illinois and Missouri before Starbucks closed its stores Tuesday, trying to capture the cultural force that the company has become.
lead_paragraph: When Starbucks shuts down across the United States, it’s hard not to take notice.

headline: If Addiction Is a Disease, Why Is Relapsing a Crime?
abstract: A case before the Massachusetts high court could mark a positive step toward rethinking addiction in the nation’s criminal justice system.
lead_paragraph: When Julie Eldred tested positive for fentanyl in 2016, 11 days into her probation for a larceny charge, she was sent to jail. Such outcomes are typical in the American criminal justice system, even though, as Ms. Eldred’s lawyer has argued, ordering a drug addict to abstain from drug use is tantamount to mandating a medical outcome — because addiction is a brain disease, and relapsing is a symptom of it.

headline: Democratic Candidate Who Criticized Israel Faces Charges of Anti-Semitism
abstract: Leslie Cockburn, the Democrat running for an open House seat in Virginia, faces G.O.P. charges of anti-Semitism for her 1991 book highly critical of Israel.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On Monday evening, at the home of a retired rabbi in Charlottesville, Va., the Democratic nominee for the Fifth Congressional District of Virginia sat down with about 40 Jewish leaders to try to defuse Virginia Republican charges that she was a “virulent anti-Semite.”

headline: Who Is Mike Parson, Missouri’s New Governor?
abstract: Mr. Parson differs little from the departing governor, Eric Greitens, in terms of policy, but greatly in terms of political style and experience.
lead_paragraph: Facing a criminal trial and possible impeachment, Gov. Eric Greitens of Missouri said on Tuesday that he would resign. He will be replaced by Lt. Gov. Michael L. Parson, a farmer and small-business owner elected in 2016, who will remain in the post through the end of Mr. Greitens’s term in January 2021.

headline: ‘Very Real, and Very Haunting’: Reporting on a Man Who Set Himself on Fire
abstract: David Buckel was a lawyer and environmental advocate. Trying to figure out why he took his life only raised more questions. Then I found a clue.
lead_paragraph: On a beautiful Saturday in April, I got an alarming news alert on my phone: A man had died after setting himself on fire in Prospect Park, Brooklyn. His name was David Buckel. He was a prominent L.G.B.T. rights lawyer who had become an advocate for the environment.

headline: Trump’s Summer Campaign Priority: Target Red-State Democratic Senators
abstract: The strategy, meant to take advantage of President Trump’s star power among core Republican supporters, will take him to six states where he can bring a message devised to stoke partisan outrage.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — President Trump is planning to focus his midterm campaigning this summer on red states with competitive Senate races where he has a deep reservoir of support and can bring a message devised to stoke partisan outrage.

headline: Dutch Official Says Russia Must Accept Blame for 2014 Attack on Jet
abstract: Foreign Minister Stef Blok, whose country is leading the inquiry into the attack on the civilian plane that killed 298 people, urged Russia to “accept its responsibility.”
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Days after a consortium of international investigators announced that Russia was the source of a missile that shot down a civilian airliner over Ukraine four years ago, the foreign minister of the Netherlands on Tuesday challenged Russia to “accept its responsibility” for the deaths of 298 people killed in the attack.

headline: Shinnecock Indian Nation and U.S.G.A. Are Close to a Deal for the U.S. Open
abstract: The tribe is expected to have a chance to profit from the Open next month at Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, which sits on a strip of Long Island once owned by the Shinnecock Nation.
lead_paragraph: After nearly a month of sometimes bumpy negotiations, the United States Golf Association, which will conduct the 118th United States Open next month at the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club on Long Island, is close to an agreement with the Shinnecock Indian Nation that will not only include the tribe in the event’s most public ceremonies but also afford the Shinnecock some financial gain from the tournament.

headline: Negotiations in Italy Push Euro to Fore, the Last Place Europe Wants It
abstract: Europe seemed to be doing so well, but now Italy is making the euro the center of a populist debate. Would Italians really leave the eurozone?

headline: China Won’t Play in This World Cup. It Still Hopes to Profit.
abstract: Scandals involving the host, Russia and soccer’s governing body, FIFA, offer opportunities for Chinese soft-power ambitions.

Alongside the slick ad campaigns for famous global brands — Visa, Adidas, Coca-Cola — there will be a proliferation of pitches from obscure companies with names like Mengniu, Vivo and Wanda. These newly minted World Cup sponsors aren’t selling much that is related to soccer; these three, for example, trade in dairy products, electric scooters and movie theaters. They all come from a country, moreover, whose national team has never scored a single World Cup goal and is not among the 32 qualifying teams this year, but which still sees itself as the future of soccer: China.

Now she has gone even farther, moving to what is perhaps her country’s most rural — and distant — 300 kilometer stretch of the Orinoco River, where she has been chronicling life along the border between Colombia and Venezuela.

headline: Inside Nxivm, the ‘Sex Cult’ That Preached Empowerment
abstract: Why did female members follow a guru named Keith Raniere, who now stands accused of sex trafficking? He made them feel like they were in control.
lead_paragraph: One winter morning in a conventional suburb outside Albany, N.Y., Nancy Salzman, the 63-year-old president of a self-improvement company named Nxivm, sat on a mahogany-colored stool in her kitchen. Her tasteful home was surrounded by other Nxivm members’ modest townhouses or capacious stone mansions that seemed to spring up out of nowhere, like mushrooms, on the suburban streets. In Salzman’s den, a photo of her with her two adult daughters hung on a wall, the three of them wearing smiles as wide as ancient Greek masks of comedy; the same happy photo served as the wallpaper on Salzman’s laptop. A hairless Sphynx cat prowled the lovely buffet of croissants and fruit on her kitchen island.

headline: Who Gets to Decide What Belongs in the ‘Canon’?
abstract: With cultural hierarchies under reconstruction, traditionalists and dissenters alike are frantically defending their views of what counts as art.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, it’s not enough to love something. You have to take that thing — album, author, song, movie, show — and do more than love it. It needs to be placed beyond mere love. You need to take that thing, wrap it in plastic or put it on a pedestal. You need to dome it under a force field so that other people’s grubby hands, opinions and inferior fandoms can’t stain or disrespect it. You need not only to certify it but also to forestall decertification. Basically, you need to make it “canon.”

There, Mr. Bailes would drive through the plains to catch sightings of lions, elephants, rhinos and zebras. At the same time, in other parts of the country, these animals were being poached or hunted and their numbers were declining.

headline: Had Two Diseases Struck at Once?
abstract: Extreme fatigue and muscle pain led to one diagnosis. Enlarged lymph nodes led to another.
lead_paragraph: It was Christmas Day when the 34-year-old woman acknowledged that something was really wrong. Her husband — like her, a physician at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. — drew the short straw and had to work that day. Home alone with her children — the baby nearly 1, the other nearly 3 — she realized she was literally too tired to put the kids to bed. When her husband got home, well after their bedtime, he scooped up the baby and the child and took them upstairs. As they disappeared into the bedroom, she struggled to follow. She held onto the banister with both hands. Lifting her legs was real work. She felt as if weights were attached to her feet. How did she get to be this tired?

headline: Who Killed the Kiev Protesters? A 3-D Model Holds the Clues
abstract: A team of civilian investigators used cellphone videos, autopsy reports and surveillance footage to reconstruct a virtual crime scene.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 20, 2014, Evelyn Nefertari, a graduate student living in western Ukraine, watched as the most violent day in her country’s recent history unfolded. On that morning, paramilitary police forces loyal to President Viktor Yanukovych clashed with protesters in Kiev, who were demonstrating against the government’s tilt toward Russia and away from economic integration with Western Europe. When the tear gas and smoke finally cleared, four police officers and 48 protesters were dead. “They were highly educated intellectuals,” Nefertari told me recently over the phone. “The nation paid a very high price for freedom.” In the aftermath of the confrontation, she decided to assemble the definitive record of what happened. “The whole country was in mourning,” she remembers. “I knew that I should do it.”

abstract: That the president vetoed a key euroskeptic cabinet minister, and that global markets sank with fear, was apparently no deterrent to new discussions on a cabinet.
lead_paragraph: ROME — If at first, or second, you don’t succeed, try, try, try again. That was the lesson from Italy’s populist parties on Wednesday. After the collapse of their attempt to form a government earlier this week, they were back at the drawing board, and on the campaign trail, giving it another go.

headline: Cancer Group Calls for Colorectal Cancer Screening Starting at Age 45
abstract: The American Cancer Society says routine screening should begin at age 45, rather than 50, reflecting the rise of colorectal cancer in younger patients.
lead_paragraph: A prominent cancer organization is for the first time recommending Americans initiate colorectal cancer screening at age 45 instead of waiting until age 50, a threshold long endorsed by many other medical groups. The new guidelines, from the American Cancer Society, would extend routine colorectal cancer screening to an additional 22 million American adults between the ages of 45 and 49 and send a clear message that colorectal cancer, which has been rising in young adults, is no longer just a disease of older people.

headline: He’s Tried to Leave ‘Star Wars’ Before. Will This Be It?
abstract: Lawrence Kasdan, whose credits include “The Empire Strikes Back,” “Return of the Jedi,” “The Force Awakens” and now “Solo,” looks back on a storied writing career.
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — The “Star Wars” films are known for their exotic aliens, sophisticated robots, sleek technology and planet-sized battle stations. That some of these movies also possess a measure of humanity is due in part to Lawrence Kasdan, the screenwriter and filmmaker George Lucas recruited to write “The Empire Strikes Back,” the first “Star Wars” sequel, and with whom Mr. Lucas wrote its follow-up, “Return of the Jedi.” On these films, Mr. Kasdan, 69, helped bring to life some of the saga’s most enduring moments, including Luke Skywalker’s fateful discovery that Darth Vader was his father.

headline: The Pugnacious Performer Who Wants to Take the Harpsichord Mainstream
abstract: Mahan Esfahani has delighted and outraged audiences in Europe and the United States — and made enemies of other players along the way.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Mahan Esfahani is a musician on a mission. “Until the harpsichord has the presence that any other mainstream instrument has, my work isn’t done,” he said.

headline: Skakel Appeal Appears Bound for U.S. Supreme Court
abstract: Connecticut prosecutors have indicated plans to ask the nation’s highest court to review Michael Skakel’s murder case.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors in Connecticut have indicated plans to appeal a state court decision overturning the murder conviction of Michael C. Skakel to the United States Supreme Court, creating yet another wrinkle in the drawn-out legal battle over a case that has captured widespread attention for decades.

headline: What to Cook Right Now
abstract: Fight those midweek blues with sweet-potato fries or a no-recipe recipe for barbecued fish.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Two days into the workweek after a long weekend and I’m sure you’re exhausted, feeling the pull of the online delivery order, the microwave-defrosted tuna surprise from the back of the freezer, the urge to pick up a few burritos and some guac on the way home, to eat hunched over the kitchen counter before exploring the very edges of the internet. (Have you seen this South Korean cop drama, “Live”?)

headline: Meet Jess Phoenix, the Volcanologist Running for Congress in California
abstract: Ms. Phoenix, one of hundreds of scientists seeking public office this year, spoke with The Times about her focus on climate change and her desire to bring evidence-based policymaking to Washington.
lead_paragraph: Sign up for California Today for the latest news on the June 5 primary and more here.

headline: What You Get for $850,000
abstract: An 1894 home in Louisville, Ky.; a Marcel Breuer house in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.; and a lakefront home in Montague, Mich.
lead_paragraph: An 1894 home in Louisville, Ky.; a Marcel Breuer house in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.; and a lakefront home in Montague, Mich.

headline: $850,000 Homes in Kentucky, New York and Michigan
abstract: An 1894 home in Louisville, a Marcel Breuer house in Poughkeepsie and a lakefront home in Montague.
lead_paragraph: WHAT An 1894 house with six bedrooms and three and a half bathrooms

headline: 122 Pregnant Whales Were Killed in Japan’s Latest Hunt. Was This Illegal?
abstract: Conservationists said the International Whaling Commission data was further evidence that Japan was killing whales for commercial purposes under the guise of scientific research.
lead_paragraph: More than 120 pregnant female whales were among 333 killed during Japan’s recent annual summer hunt off the coast of Antarctica, according to a new report.

headline: Canada’s Troubled Pipeline Projects
abstract: The decision to nationalize the Trans Mountain pipeline underscores the country’s growing ambivalence about fossil fuels.
lead_paragraph: While living in Calgary, the headquarters of Canada’s oil and gas industry, I occasionally heard people in the business say their pipelines were cursed. The country was brimming with oil and gas, and yet battles over proposed pipelines had limited the ability of producers to get those resources to market.

headline: What to Expect the 264th Month
abstract: Being a parent gets hard when you’re trying to decide when to stop.
lead_paragraph: Our youngest child, Sean, walked across the stage in his graduation robe. Earlier in the day, he had been inducted into the Order of the Engineer and into Phi Beta Kappa, the honors society. Now, as he prepared to throw his mortarboard skyward, a thought crossed my mind: I might possibly be the worst parent in the world.

headline: Trump Again Says He Wishes Sessions Were Not Attorney General
abstract: President Trump said on Twitter that he wished he had chosen another good lawyer to be his attorney general.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Wednesday that he wished he had chosen another lawyer to be his attorney general, instead of Jeff Sessions, who recused himself from the Russia investigation early in the Trump administration.

headline: After Arkady Babchenko’s ‘Murder,’ a Twist Was Revealed. By Him.
abstract: Ukraine says the death in Kiev of Arkady Babchenko was staged to thwart an assassination plot against him by Russia. It drew wide protests.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The assassination bore all the hallmarks of yet another contract killing carried out in the murky shadows of the conflict pitting Russia against Ukraine.

headline: ‘One Sings, the Other Doesn’t’: Agnès Varda’s Polarizing Paean to Sisterhood
abstract: Is Ms. Varda’s long unavailable feminist musical as divisive as it was 1977? Watch it now in a new 2K digital restoration and decide.
lead_paragraph: Despite its amiable spirit of inclusion, Agnès Varda’s pop paean to sisterhood, “One Sings, the Other Doesn’t,” proved divisive from the night it opened the 1977 New York Film Festival.

headline: Dad Left a Big Impression: The Renoir Family Inheritance
abstract: The filmmaker Jean Renoir did not always treasure his father’s paintings — but that changed. He spoke of Pierre-Auguste Renoir as the central influence of his life.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — “I think that a great painter is even rarer than a great film director,” Jean Renoir said. It was 1967, and that French filmmaker was sitting on the bank of the river Ource, amiably chatting during the making of a documentary by Jacques Rivette, a New Wave director who idolized Renoir’s “Grand Illusion,” “The Crime of Monsieur Lange” and the masterpiece “The Rules of the Game.”

headline: A Designer’s Favorite Possession: A Guitar That Reminds Him of Home
abstract: Entireworld’s Scott Sternberg on the music shop that defined his adolescence — and the instrument he got there.
lead_paragraph: In this series for T, Emily Spivack, the author of “Worn Stories,” interviews creative types about their most prized possessions. In April, the designer Scott Sternberg, formerly of Band of Outsiders, launched Entireworld, a line of  well-made men’s and women’s clothing intended for everyday wear. Here, he describes the music shop that was a sanctuary for him as an adolescent, and the guitar he purchased there.

headline: Empellón Group Will Take Over Salvation Taco
abstract: As Ken Friedman and April Bloomfield work to divide their holdings in the wake of a sex-harassment scandal, the chef Alex Stupak will now run their Midtown taqueria.
lead_paragraph: Alex Stupak, the chef and co-owner of the three Empellón restaurants in Manhattan, signed an agreement on Tuesday to take over Salvation Taco, the popular taqueria in the Pod 39 Hotel in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: How Technology Is Changing Visual Art
abstract: Minh Uong, a visual editor at The Times, uses both low- and high-tech tools to create editorial art, but tech does not necessarily make it easier to become a professional illustrator.
lead_paragraph: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Minh Uong, a visual editor for The Times’s business section, discussed the tech he’s using.

headline: Roseanne Barr’s Ambien Defense Is Disputed: ‘Racism Is Not a Known Side Effect’
abstract: Sanofi U.S. responded after Ms. Barr said she had taken the sleep aid before sending a racist tweet that led to the cancellation of her show.
lead_paragraph: Roseanne Barr said she was “Ambien tweeting” when she wrote racist remarks on Twitter that compared a black former Obama administration official to an ape, a comment that led ABC to cancel her television show.

headline: Big Banks to Get a Break From Limits on Risky Trading
abstract: The Fed proposed loosening the Volcker Rule, which prevents banks from trading with depositors’ money. The move is expected to give banks more room for complex trades.
lead_paragraph: Big banks are getting a big reprieve from a postcrisis rule aimed at curbing risky behavior on Wall Street.

headline: The Privacy Lawyer Giving Big Tech an $8.8 Billion Headache
abstract: With the enactment of new privacy rules in Europe, it isn’t just regulators going after Big Tech: Advocates like Max Schrems are already filing lawsuits.
lead_paragraph: At midnight last Friday, the European Union’s long-awaited new data-protection rules, known as the General Data Protection Regulation, officially kicked in.

headline: Review: In ‘American Animals,’ These Guys Didn’t Visit the Library to Study
abstract: A movie about a real-life rare-book heist.
lead_paragraph: In December 2004, in the midst of final exams, four young men robbed the rare-book room at the library of Transylvania University in Lexington, Ky. A Vanity Fair article a few years later described the heist as one part “Ocean’s 11,” one part “Harold & Kumar,” which might raise your hopes for “American Animals,” a new movie that reconstructs the crime. But the film, written and directed by Bart Layton, can’t quite decide what it wants to be: a slick, speedy caper; a goofball comedy; or a commentary on the state of the American soul. It’s none of those — a tame and toothless creature that is neither fish nor fowl.

headline: Behind the Cover: The Empowerment Cult
abstract: A new video series goes inside the process for creating the covers of The New York Times Magazine.

headline: Free Cash to Fight Income Inequality? California City Is First in U.S. to Try
abstract: Long plagued by poverty and desperation, Stockton, Calif., is testing universal basic income as a means of improving the lives of its residents.
lead_paragraph: STOCKTON, Calif. — This town in California’s Central Valley has long functioned as a display case for wrenching troubles afflicting American life: The housing bust that turned Stockton into an epicenter of a national foreclosure disaster and plunged the city into bankruptcy. The homeless people clustered in tents along the railroad tracks. Boarded-up storefronts on cracked sidewalks. Gang violence.

headline: Raheem Sterling’s Gun Tattoo Fuels U.K. Tabloid Outrage
abstract: Mr. Sterling, 23, is a star in English soccer but his decision to have an image of a rifle on his calf has stirred controversy. Not for the first time.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — He has said he has the kind of face that people just don’t like — “the ‘I don’t like face’” — and, in the past few days, quite a few people have tried to prove him right in what seems a peculiarly British cocktail of race, envy and, of course, tabloid newspapers.

headline: Date Set for 21st Century Fox Shareholders to Vote on Disney Deal
abstract: 21st Century Fox and Disney shareholders are scheduled to vote on the proposed deal simultaneously on July 10. The new timeline puts pressure on Comcast, which is considering an all-cash bid for the Fox assets.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A firmer timeline for the expected tug-of-war for 21st Century Fox has been established.

headline: Trump Responds to Fury Over ‘Roseanne,’ but Not Her Racist Remarks
abstract: President Trump acknowledged the furor over a racist Twitter post made by Roseanne Barr, but focused on the apology issued by ABC.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was not the racist comment that made the president angry. It was the apology from ABC.

abstract: Take Justin Trudeau’s memoir on a drive to Canada. Read by Colm Feore.
lead_paragraph: Take Justin Trudeau’s memoir on a drive to Canada. Read by Colm Feore.

headline: India and Pakistan Agree to Truce on Kashmir Border
abstract: The agreement between the nuclear-armed neighbors prompted hope and skepticism from residents of the region, which has been suffering its worst violence in years.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — India and Pakistan have declared a cease-fire along their disputed border in Kashmir, a move welcomed with uneasiness among the population in the area, where a series of such agreements have failed in the past.

headline: La MaMa Moves! Remains a Freewheeling Home for Dance
abstract: The festival’s refreshingly old-school mix this year included works exploring identity and aging, as well as a mixed bill that proved most realized.
lead_paragraph: Built into the title of La MaMa Moves! Dance Festival, the late-spring extravaganza now in its 13th season, is an uninhibited enthusiasm for dance (that exclamation point!). The name also reflects the unpretentious nature of the programming, as shaped by the freewheeling tastes of the festival’s longtime curator, Nicky Paraiso. At a time when dance programming often takes cues from museum exhibitions, cohering around specific themes or provocations, there’s something refreshingly old school in the looser La MaMa Moves! approach.

headline: Clouds Over Manhattanhenge
abstract: Manhattanhenge may be a silly reason to gather, especially when the sunset doesn’t cooperate. But it’s still a party.
lead_paragraph: It is widely known that when the ancient Druids built Manhattan, hundreds of years before the dawn of history, they envisaged future Druids jumping into the middle of 42nd Street, cellphone cameras in hand, to mark the semiannual occasions when the sun set in exact alignment with the city’s east-west thoroughfares. (This was before marauding SantaCon bands wiped out the Druids.)

headline: They Let Their 15-Year-Old Son Smoke Pot to Stop His Seizures. Georgia Took Him Away.
abstract: The parents say the boy’s seizures stopped for 71 days while smoking pot, but they were arrested and he was taken to a group home.
lead_paragraph: The pharmaceuticals weren’t working. The 15-year-old boy was having several seizures per day, and his parents were concerned his life was in danger.

headline: Triple Jeopardy in College Sexual Assault Case Ends an N.F.L. Career
abstract: Keith Mumphery was twice cleared of an alleged sexual assault. Then he was tried a third time, without even knowing it. And then his life collapsed.
lead_paragraph: This is a story of a rape accusation that would not die and a misshapen version of college justice meted out in three chapters.

headline: Is Gucci Stylish or Tacky? Yes
abstract: The idea of luxury has come to include the stylish and unstylish, the well-to-do and the aspiring, the sincere and the ironic, the real and the fake.
lead_paragraph: The salesclerks wear head-to-toe logo tracksuits ($2,300 for the jacket, $1,500 for the pants) at the new Gucci store on Wooster Street, a cultish cadre of caterers and nodders with the patience of saints gamely explaining the differences between the embroidered sneakers and showing couples in worn-in flip-flops 20 or 30 yowza-wowza sunglass options.

headline: From ‘Peasprout Chen’
abstract: The spirited heroine in Henry Lien’s fantasy debut goes off alone to master “the beautiful and deadly art of martial skating.” Read by Nancy Wu.
lead_paragraph: The spirited heroine in Henry Lien’s fantasy debut goes off alone to master “the beautiful and deadly art of martial skating.” Read by Nancy Wu.

abstract: Rachel Hartman’s heroine navigates a medieval world shot through with modern concerns. Read by Katharine McEwan.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Hartman’s heroine navigates a medieval world shot through with modern concerns. Read by Katharine McEwan.
